 I think you're less likely to be audited using one of the software programs because they are simple, accurate, and like Daewoo said, don't have a lot of "wiggle room".
 
 Their downfall comes when your tax situation gets complicated - multiple incomes, investments, stock options, etc...
 
 My only other concern is that I'm maximizing my return, I don't always trust that the software programs are getting me every last dollar, though I think they are pretty thorough.
 
 If you have a really good accountant, they can pretty much pay for their services by maximizing your return - again - given that there your taxes are sufficiently complex.  Anyhoo,
 
 Short answer - if I was you I'd go for it. Worst case scenario you spent $20 on the software and then decide not to use it.
